10:32 You meant to say that v_x is v*cos(theta).

Because in the last part of the last exercise, 800m is being used as the displacement, not height. Since in the displacement it is going down, then it has to be negative. Now, if you are talking about the equation of which he changed the signs of the other numbers but not -800, that's because -800 remained on the left side of the equation as it was before.

I used the same equation and got 10s. The reason why you got the wrong answer is because Vy is not 0m/s. You have to find the velocity right before it hits the ground. I used the equation Vy^2=Vi^2-2gh to find the final velocity. You would then plug that answer into Vy=Vyo-gt to find the time. hope that helps !!

The ball is not exerting any force itself, rather the only force acting on it is gravity (ignoring air resistance) and since gravity pulls things down (if you're standing on the earth) it must be negative
Any object going up or right has a positive acceleration, and any object going down or left has a negative acceleration
pythagorean theorem
@twinicebear775  yea I got that but what is the logic behind using this specific equation for finding the velocity of an object right before it hits the ground.

The path that the ball takes is v and since v is a vector it's components are vx and vy. So as we can see, v along with it's components is a right triangle, that can be solved via pythagorean theorem.  As for why before it hits the ground, this may be because the ball could come back up and change it's direction, velocity and momentum. Soo, that could change stuff
Nd the part about why is my perception, btw. But i hope my ans is helpful. :)

The negative is just the direction. When you throw the ball upwards you get positive acceleration(+9.8m/s) for the first part but after it’s start to go down then it becomes negative(-9.8m/s)

@smdclassic  Thanks for the response but not you are correct. when something throw up ward the velocity is up but the acceleration due to gravity is always towards the center so that the velocity and acceleration due to gravity different direction. Generally in my understanding in up ward motion the acceleration due to gravity will be negative and in down ward motion both the velocity and acceleration due to gravity are the same direction so the gravity will be positive.
@smdclassic  ohhhhh

Because acceleration due to gravity is always negative (the up and right directions are always positive, whereas down and left directions are always negative)  Gravity always pulls things down, so it's negative   Hope this helps :)
